areaSection: El Verger sits on the northern Costa Blanca, a whitewashed village where tradition meets modern convenience. Unlike overdeveloped beach towns, El Verger maintains authentic charm while providing all contemporary amenities. The village enjoys 320 days of annual sunshine, crystalline Mediterranean waters, and a backdrop of gentle mountains that soften every sunset. Located approximately 80 kilometers from Valencia and 50 kilometers north of the busier coastal centers, El Verger attracts those seeking peaceful authenticity without isolation. The microclimate here is particularly pleasant: warm summers moderated by sea breezes, mild winters perfect for outdoor living. This positioning makes it ideal for year-round holidays rather than seasonal tourism. The local community reflects decades of smart European settlement, creating a welcoming international presence while maintaining Spanish cultural character.
lifestyleSection: Life in El Verger revolves around leisure and wellbeing. Your mornings might begin with coffee at a beach chiringuito watching sailboats, afternoons exploring local seafood restaurants where English is spoken, evenings strolling through established expat neighborhoods where international friendships flourish. The established international community means excellent English speakers, healthcare with English-speaking doctors, and international schools nearby. Weekly markets burst with seasonal produce and local crafts. Mercadona and Lidl supermarkets cater to international dietary preferences. Healthcare is accessible and modern—regional hospitals within 30 minutes, private clinics offering immediate attention. Bus connections link you to nearby towns, though a car provides preferred flexibility. Weekends bring Blue Flag beaches within 20 minutes, championship golf courses for enthusiasts, and charming towns for cultural exploration. This is lifestyle living without constant tourist chaos—a genuine Mediterranean daily rhythm.

faqs.question: Can foreigners buy property in Spain?
faqs.answer: Yes. UK citizens and most international buyers face no restrictions purchasing Spanish property. You'll need an NIE (Spanish tax number), which your solicitor obtains during conveyancing. Costs include 6-8% transfer taxes, legal fees (€1,500-2,500), and notary fees. Professional English-speaking solicitors handle all documentation, making the process straightforward.

faqs.question: What are the costs of buying property in Spain?
faqs.answer: Purchase price represents roughly 85-90% of total outlay. Additional costs include: transfer tax (6-8%), legal/notary fees (€1,500-2,500), property registration (€300-500), and optional surveyor (€500-800). Annual ownership costs include minimal property taxes (typically €200-400), insurance (€300-600), and utilities. Professional advisors provide transparent cost breakdowns before commitment.

faqs.question: How much are property taxes in Spain?
faqs.answer: Annual property taxes average €200-400 for holiday homes this value. No wealth tax applies to foreign property owners. Transfer taxes at purchase equal 6-8% of acquisition price. Spanish taxation is straightforward and transparent—English-speaking accountants charge €300-600 annually for complete tax compliance. No VAT applies to residential properties.

faqs.question: Can I get a mortgage in Spain as a foreigner?
faqs.answer: Yes. Spanish banks offer mortgages to foreign buyers—typically 50-70% loan-to-value for non-residents. Interest rates approximate 3-4% depending on credit profile and deposit percentage. UK lenders increasingly offer Spanish mortgages directly. Alternatively, many international buyers purchase with cash given competitive pricing. Professional mortgage brokers provide transparent guidance on best financing options.

faqs.question: What is the weather like on Costa Blanca?
faqs.answer: Mediterranean climate perfection: 320 annual sunshine days, average temperatures 12°C winter/29°C summer. Summers are warm and dry with sea breezes moderating heat. Winters are mild—frost is rare, snow non-existent. Rainfall concentrates in autumn and spring. Unlike northern Europe, sunshine is consistent and reliable, enabling year-round outdoor living and beach days.
